sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: gThumb is an image viewer and browser written for the GNOME environment. It lets you browse your hard disk, showing you thumbnails of image files. It also lets you view single files (including GIF animations), add comments to images, organize images in catalogs, print images, view slideshows, set your desktop background, and more.
To run gThumb, select its entry from the Graphics submenu of the Applications menu, or type gthumb on the command line. If you start gThumb from the command line you can specify a starting folder :
or a list of files to view :

The above example will pop up three windows, one shows you the files with a jpg extension in the current folder, and the others two will show you respectively the content of folder1 and folder2.

sect1.title: Browsing folders
sect1.para:
When you first launch gThumb the main window pops up, four areas give you information about the current folder :
The location bar, which contains the current folder name.
The folder list, which shows you the sub-folders contained in the current folder.
The image list, which shows you the images in the current folder.
The status bar, where you can read the total number of images contained in the current folder, and the total size of all these images; the number of the selected images and the total size of these images.
The main window
The main window

If you want to change folder you have two options, clicking on the folder name in the folder list, or typing the folder name in the location entry. When using the location entry you can press CtrlTAB to try to automatically complete the folder name, this simplify the typing of long names.

To go to a previously visited folder you can use the GoBack command or click on the Go menu that contains a list of the most recently visited ones. In this menu keeping the pointer on a folder name will display the full path of the folder in the statusbar.

Frequently used folders can be added to the bookmark list for rapid access. Just go the folder and press CtrlD or use the command BookmarksAdd Bookmark. For removing or rearrange bookmarks in a different order use the BookmarksEdit Bookmarks command.

To sort the images in a different order use the Sort images submenu in the View menu, use ViewRefresh to reload the current folder, click on ViewThumbnails to view or hide the thumbnails in the images list.
To move, copy and rename images, select the images and use the corresponding command in the Edit menu.
To open an image, or a series of images, with an external program select the image and use the FileOpen images with command.

sect1.title: Viewing images
sect1.para: In order to view an image just click on its thumbnail and the image will be visualized in the viewer pane. If the image doesn't fit the viewer pane you can give more space to the viewer hiding the browser, this can be accoplished pressing the Return key, pressing it again the browser will be re-displayed. Another way of viewing a big image is to view it in full screen mode, type V to activate/disactivate the full screen mode.
Mouse operations :

entry.para: Holding down the left button and moving the mouse

sect1.para:
Another way of moving the image is by the navigation button :
located in the right bottom corner of the viewer window when the images does not fit in the window. Clicking and holding this button will show you a preview of the image. Moving the mouse you will move the image to the desired position.

sect2.title: Altering images
sect2.para: There are a set of commands, located in the Image menu, that let you modify the current image.

entry.para: Create a mirror image by reflecting the image scanlines in the vertical direction.
Create a mirror image by reflecting the image scanlines in the horizontal direction (as in a mirror).
Change image size performing a zoom in or out.
View the image in black and white.

sect2.para: Note that this modifications do not change the image file, and if you want to view the original image just click on its thumbnail again or use the FileRevert command.

To save the modified image use the FileSave As command. Images can be saved in JPEG, PNG, TGA, TIFF formats. Each image format have some option that can be changed with a dialog that pops up after having entered the image filename. All the dialogs remember the last specified options.

sect1.title: Printing images
sect1.para: Click on the image you want to print, then select the FilePrint image command.

The Print setup dialog lets you
Choose the paper format and orientation,
Choose the printer to use,
Choose the size of the image,
Move the image clicking on it with the left mouse button and dragging the image where you want to put it.
Recentre the image on the page use the Center on Page button.
When you are ready to print press the Print button.

sect1.title: Adding comments to images
sect1.para: In order to add a comment to an image select the image and use the EditEdit comment command or type C.

Comments are structured in various parts :
Comment: a free text describing the picture.
Place: the place the picture represents.
Date: the date the picture was taken.
Categories: a series of categories the image belongs to. Categories are usefull for doing complex searches, as described in .
The "Edit Comment" dialog
The Edit Comment dialog

Image comments are displayed in the image list in italic text above the image filename. If the comment is too long the simbol "[..]" is appended to the displayed part of the comment to signal you that not all the comment is visible, to view the whole comment use the image properties dialog that can be displayed using the FileProperties command or pressing I.
To delete a comment use the command : EditDelete comment.

You can even add a comment to multiple images, in this case the comment dialog will fill in the fields that are the same for all images leaving all other fields empty, and the Save only changed fields option is enabled. If this option is active (default) you can change one or more fields of the comment of many images leaving all other fields unchanged.

Comments are not embedded in image files they are saved separately, this means that if you move the images or the folders images are in with other programs you will lose the comments. Comments are saved in the folder $(HOME)/.gnome2/gthumb/comments.

sect1.title: Organizing images in catalogs
sect1.para: Catalogs lets you organize images without moving them from a folder to another, think of them as "playlists" for images. The following is the list of operations you can perform with a catalog :

listitem.para: Viewing the list of catalogs : Press Alt2 or select the ViewShow/HideCatalogs command.
Adding images to a catalog : Select the images you want to add to a catalog and use the Edit Add to Catalog command to select or create a catalog.
Deleting images from a catalog : Select the images you want to delete then use the Edit Delete from Catalog command.

Renaming, Deleting or Moving catalogs : Select the catalog and use the corrisponding command in the File menu, or use the context menu pressing the right mouse button on the name of the catalog in the catalog list.

sect1.para: If you want to go to the folder that contains an image, select the image and use the GoGo to the image folder command or press AltEnd.

Catalogs are not updated when you move images, if you want a more flexible catalog you can use the searches described in , searches are catalogs with search data attached, after moving images you can redo the search to get the catalog updated. Catalogs are saved in the folder $(HOME)/.gnome2/gthumb/collections.

sect1.title: Advanced Tools

sect2.title: Slide Show
sect2.para: You can start a slide show of the images in the current folder by pressing S or selecting the View Slide Show menu item. To stop the Slideshow press S again.

Switching on/off the full screen mode does not stop the slide show. If the Switch to full screen option is on then the slide show is started in fullscreen mode and exiting from the fullscreen mode stops the slide show.
The slideshow is interrupted when changing folder or re-loading the current one.

If you want to do a presentation with images you do not need this tool, instead you can simply set the fullscreen mode and press Space or Page Down to view the next image, and b or Page Up to view the previous image.

sect2.title: Wallpaper
sect2.para:
If you want to set the selected image as desktop wallpaper select the menu Set Image as Wallpaper from the Tools menu. The menu contains four ways of setting the wallpaper :
Centered : the image will be centered on the desktop.
Tiled : the image will be duplicated on the desktop as tiles on the floor.
Stretched : the image will be scaled to fill the desktop changing proportions if needed.
Scaled : the image will be scaled to fill the desktop mantaining the aspect ratio.

If you want to restore the old wallpaper use the
Tools Set Image as Wallpaper Restore item.

sect1.sect2:
Find Images
The Find Images tool lets you find images on you hard disk and save the result as a catalog. To use this tool select the Find... item from the Edit menu.
The "Find" dialog
The Find dialog
with an image editor
When the dialog pops up, you can specify a file name or a pattern in the File name entry, for example :
foo.jpg : will search for files named foo.jpg
*.png : will search for files with the png extension.
*.gif; *.jpg : will search for files with the gif or jpg extension. with an image editor
Other search rules:
Start at : The folder the search will start from.
Include sub-folder : Whether to search even in the sub folders.
Comment : A list of phrases the comment of the image must contain, for example:
paolo : will search for images that have "paolo" in the comment.
my birthday : will search for images that have "my birthday" in the comment.
holiday ; rome : will search for images that have "holiday" OR "rome" in the comment.
holiday in rome ; my birthday : will search for images that have "holiday in rome" OR "my birthday" in the comment.
Place : A list of phrases the place field of the comment must contain, for example:
rome : will search for images that have "rome" in the place field.
paris ; rome ; london : will search for images that have "paris" OR "rome" OR "london" in the place field.
Date : The criteria the date field of the comment must respect:
any : the date field is ignored.
before, equal to, after : the date must be less recent, equal to or more recent than the date specified.
Categories : The list of categories an images must belong to, for example :
family : images must have "family" has one of their keywords.
me, family : images must have "family" and/or "me" in the keywords list.
You can choose to search for images that belongs to all the specified categories or at least to one of them, checking the corresponding option.
If you use more than one criteria images must respect all of them.
The search is always case insensitive.
The "Search Progress" dialog
The Search Progress dialog
Pressing the Search button the search will start. Once the search has finished you will see the list of files that matches your search, if you want to see these files press the View button, if you want to make another search press the New Search button.
The "Search Result" catalog
The "Search Result" catalog
If you choose to view the files, a catalog named Search Results will be created and visualized automatically. A catalog created in this way has a special icon, a magnifier, this is because on this type of catalog you can perform two more operations : Edit Search and Redo Search .
These operations can be selected from the File Search menu, or from the menu that pops up when pressing the right mouse button on the catalog name.
The Edit Search command lets you re-edit the search rules, while Redo Search lets you restart the search, at the end of the search you can decide whether to save the result in the catalog or not.

sect2.title: Index Image
sect2.para: An index image is an image that contains small previews of a series of images. If you want to create an index image select the images you want to insert in the index and then use the ToolsCreate Index Image command.

sect2.title: Rotate JPEG
sect2.para: Usually if you want to rotate an image you have to open the image with an editor, rotate the image and save it. This works good for image formats such as PNG or GIF, but results in a loss of quality for JPEG images.
If you want to rotate JPEG images without losing quality you can select the images you want to rotate and use the ToolsRotate JPEG command.

If you select the Apply to all images option the rotation is applied to the currently displayed image as well as to all the remaining images, otherwise, once the rotation has been performed on the current image, the next image in the selection is displayed, and you can choose another type of rotation.
If the selection contains some non-JPEG images, they are simply ignored.

sect1.title: Preferences
sect1.para: To configure gThumb, open Preferences dialog by selecting EditPreferences .
This dialog contains four tabs described in detail below. At the bottom of the dialog window, you'll find the following buttons:

listitem.para: OK: saves the settings and closes the dialog.
Apply: saves the settings without closing the dialog, so that you can see the effect of your changes. If you are not satisfied with the results, you can continue editing the settings.
Close: closes the dialog without saving the changes.
Help: shows this manual.

sect2.title: General Tab
sect2.para: This tab allows you to set the following options:

listitem.para: Select the layout of gThumb main window, i.e. the positions of directory list window, the image (thumbnail) list window, and the main image viewer window.
The toolbar style
Directory to show on startup
The history length, that is the maximal number of locations to show in Go menu. The default is 15.

sect2.title: Browser Tab
sect2.para: In this tab, you can configure the following options:

listitem.para: This option (which you can activate simply pressing T) controls whether gThumb should show thumbnails.
This option controls whether gThumb should show comments (including date and place) in the image list. By default, >humb; shows the comment as a caption under the thumbnail.

This option controls whether gThumb should show files with the names starting with dot (.). These files usually contain system information or applications settings. Since these files almost never contain user data, by default they are not shown by file manager and other applications. In most cases, you should leave this option unselected.

Here you can select the thumbnails size to your taste. By default, gThumb display thumbnails of size 95x95 pixels. If you like to view as much thumbnails as possible select a small thumbnail size, if you want to view detailed thumbnails select a big size. The other option lets you decide whether to save the thumbnails or not, saving thumbnails is highly recommended because this let you speed up browsing of folders you already visited, the drawback is that thumbnails occupy disk space so if your free space is limited you may prefer to disable this option but in most cases you should leave this option selected.

Here you can choose whether to change folder by doing a single or a double click on the folder name. The single click can be usefull if you are used to quickly browse your hard disk searching for images. The default behaviour is to follow the Nautilus file manager policy. Furthermore you can select whether gThumb should ask for confirmation before deleting an image or a catalog, and whether gThumb should determine image type by looking at the file extension or by looking at the file content. Determining file type from the content is more reliable (some applications may create files with extension not matching the actual file type) but slower. If you have a fast system, select Determine image type from content.

sect2.title: Viewer Tab
sect2.para: This tab contains options for viewer window:

listitem.para: This controls the method used for showing rescaled image. Possible choices are high quality (slow on old machines or when viewing big images) and low quality (always fast).
Controls initial zoom level to use for an image.
Controls the background used for partly transparent images. By default the transparent part of the image is replaced the window background color,that is the none option.
This option only has effect for partly transparent images and only if checked transparency type was selected. It controls the size and colors of checker board pattern used for the background.

sect2.title: Slide Show Tab
sect2.para: This tab contains the options controlling slide show mode (which you can start by selecting Tools Slide Show or by using CtrlS shortcut). The options include direction (forward/backwards), and delay between images. You can also specify whether the slide show should wrap around (i.e., after showing the last image start again form the beginning) and automatically switch to fullscreen mode.
